frameDefinitions: The Payer is (legally) forced to pay a Fine by an official Speaker as a punishment for some action (the Reason).
This frame concerns the infliction of punishment in return for a wrong suffered.
In this frame, a Communicator judges the Addressee and then communicates that appraisal directly to the Addressee.
An Agent (the punisher or rewarder) performs a Response_action on an Evaluee for a Reason, the Evaluee's actions or beliefs.
These are words describing situations in which a Perpetrator takes Goods from a  Victim or a Source.
An Agent has committed a Wrong in the past and is making Amends for it.
frameExamples: They were <t>fined</t> approximately $3.1 billion dollars for their knowing, malicious injury to consumers.
(1) They took <t>revenge</t> for the deaths of two loyalist prisoners.
The principal <t>rebuked</t> the student for cheating on the exam.
His <t>punishment</t> of the prisoners was too harsh.
I can't believe he <t>pickpocketed</t> my gold watch !
He <t>atoned</t> for his sin with good works.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the person who imposes the <fen>Fine</fen> upon the <fen>Payer</fen>.
The <fen>Payer</fen> is the person or thing about whom/which a judgment is made.  With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:

Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <t>Reason</t> for the Judge's judgment. It is usually a <ment>for</ment>-PP, e.g. I <t>admire</t> you <fex name='Reason'>for your intellect</fex>. For some words in this domain, the Reason frame element is obligatory. That is to say, the overt expression of this frame element may only be omitted when the reason for the judgment is understood from context. For example, the sentence 'I <t>blame</t> you!' can only be uttered when it is clear what the addressee is being blamed for.
The money given to expiate some debt for transgression.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Avenger</fen> exacts revenge from the <fen>Offender</fen> for the <fen>Injury</fen>.
The <fen>Offender</fen> has committed the earlier <fen>Injury</fen> for which the <fen>Avenger</fen> seeks revenge.
The <fen>Avenger</fen> carries out a <fen>Punishment</fen> in order to exact revenge on the <fen>Offender</fen>.

The <fen>Injury</fen> is the injurious action committed by the <fen>Offender</fen> against the <fen>Injured_Party</fen>. This Frame Element need not always be realized, although it is conceptually necessary.

This frame element identifies the constituent that encodes who or what suffered the <fen>Injury</fen> at the hands of the <fen>Offender</fen>. Sometimes, an abstract concept such a person's honour or their blood is presented as the element that has suffered the <fen>Injury</fen>. These also constitute instances of  <fen>Injured_party</fen>
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the revenge occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the revenge occurs.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates a judgment to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The <fen>Addressee</fen> is jduged by the <fen>Communicator</fen> and receives the message of approval or disapproval.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject on which the <fen>Addressee</fen> is being judged.
The <fen>Reason</fen> is why the Communicator forms the type of judgment they form.
The <fen>Medium</fen> identifies the physical or abstract entity in which the judgment is conveyed.
An action or entity under the control of the <fen>Communicator</fen> that expresses the criticism or praise directed towards the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The point in time at which the <fen>Communicator</fen> berates or compliments the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Communicator</fen> admonishes the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<fen>Evaluee</fen> is the person or thing about whom/which a judgment has made and to whom reward/punishment is dealt. With verbs, the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is typically expressed as Object.
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <fen>Reason</fen> for the <fen>Agent</fen>'s judgment. It is usually a 'for'-PP, e.g.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person doing the rewarding or punishing.
The reward or punishment given to the <fen>Evaluee</fen> by the <fen>Agent</fen>.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
<fen>Perpetrator</fen> is the person (or other agent) that takes the goods away.
<fen>Victim</fen> is the person (or other sentient being or group) that owns the goods before they are taken away by the perpetrator.
<fen>Goods</fen> is anything (including labor, time, or legal rights) that can be taken away.
<fen>Source</fen> is the initial location of the goods, before they change location.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the theft occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the theft occurs.
The <fen>Agent</fen> has committed a <fen>Wrong</fen> and is making <fen>Amends</fen>.
<fen>Wrong</fen> identifies the act committed by the <fen>Agent</fen> for which <fen>Amends</fen> are made.
<fen>Amends</fen> marks expressions that indicate what the <fen>Agent</fen> does to compensate for the <fen>Wrong</fen> that was committed.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> atones for the <fen>Wrong</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Agent</fen> expiates the <fen>Wrong</fen>.
listRoleExamples: The mental control officer fined <fex>you</fex> for your lack of diligence.
Pat paid <fex>14 dollars</fex> in fines.
<fex>We</fex> want to avenge her.
Jo had the affair as a kind of revenge <fex>against Pat</fex>.
The team took revenge <fex>with a resounding victory</fex>.
The team sought revenge <fex>for their 4-1 defeat last month</fex>.
Sam's brothers avenged <fex>him</fex>.
The teacher scolded the children <fex>about their meessy cookie eating</fex>.
The principal rebuked the student <fex>for cheating on the exam</fex>.
Though she had killed him so long ago, she could still see his jeering <fex>smile</fex>.
She complimented me <fex>almost every morning</fex> on my smart starched shirts.
We were scolded <fex>in the kitchen</fex> by the biggest cook you've ever seen.
The boss rewarded <fex>you</fex> for your diligence.
I punished him <fex>for his impudence</fex>.
<fex>Jake's</fex> rewards to his best workers were very generous.
If a person be guilty of impiety let him be punished <fex>with death</fex>.
<fex>Leslie</fex> stole the watch from Kim.
Leslie stole the watch <fex>from Kim</fex>.
Leslie STOLE <fex>the watch</fex> from Kim.
Leslie stole the watch <fex>from the table</fex>.
Leslie STOLE the watch from Kim <fex>at dusk</fex>.
Leslie STOLE the watch from Kim <fex>in the park</fex>.
<fex>Syria</fex> has atoned for its support of Iraq.
Smithers is atoning <fex>for his misspent youth</fex>.
He atoned for his sin <fex>with good works</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Fall from Heaven: Age of Ice
